a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
shows  "floor t = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $t$ be the smallest positive real number for which $\cos t = \cos t^{\circ}$.  (We are taking the cosine of $t$ radians on the left and of $t$ degrees on the right.)  Compute $\lfloor t\rfloor$, the greatest integer less than $t$. The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Imagine two identical clock hands, each rotating counterclockwise and both initially pointing directly to the right. If one of them rotates at 1 radian per second while the other rotates at $1^{\circ}$ per second, then the faster one will sweep out an angle of $t$ radians at the same time that the slower one travels through $t$ degrees.
 We wish to know approximately when the cosines of the corresponding angles will be equal, i.e. when the $x$-coordinates of the tips of the clock hands will be the same. Clearly this will occur when the faster hand has rotated nearly all the way around the circle.
 After six seconds the slow hand will have rotated only $6^{\circ}$, while the fast hand will have traveled around 6 radians, which is still further than $6^{\circ}$ away from its starting point. (Recall that 1 radian is equal to $\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}$, which is a couple degrees less than $60^{\circ}$.)
 Therefore the $x$-coordinates will not yet be equal for the first time, but will be very close.
 We conclude that $\lfloor t\rfloor=\boxed{6}$. The interested reader may wish to compute the exact value of $t$ for which this occurs. You should find that $t= \frac{360\pi}{\pi+180}\approx 6.1754$.
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
shows  "floor t = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find a positive real number $t$ such that the cosine of $t$ is equal to the cosine of $t$ times $\pi$ divided by $180$. The number $t$ should be such that, when rounded down, it becomes $6$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
shows  "floor t = 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $t$ be the smallest positive real number for which $\cos t = \cos t^{\circ}$.  (We are taking the cosine of $t$ radians on the left and of $t$ degrees on the right.)  Compute $\lfloor t\rfloor$, the greatest integer less than $t$. The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Imagine two identical clock hands, each rotating counterclockwise and both initially pointing directly to the right. If one of them rotates at 1 radian per second while the other rotates at $1^{\circ}$ per second, then the faster one will sweep out an angle of $t$ radians at the same time that the slower one travels through $t$ degrees.

 After six seconds the slow hand will have rotated only $6^{\circ}$, while the fast hand will have traveled around 6 radians, which is still further than $6^{\circ}$ away from its starting point. (Recall that 1 radian is equal to $\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}$, which is a couple degrees less than $60^{\circ}$.)

 We conclude that $\lfloor t\rfloor=\boxed{6}$. The interested reader may wish to compute the exact value of $t$ for which this occurs. You should find that $t= \frac{360\pi}{\pi+180}\approx 6.1754$.
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
shows  "floor t = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a real number $t > 0$ such that the cosine of $t$ equals the cosine of $t$ times $\frac{\pi}{180}$, show that the greatest integer less than or equal to $t$ is $6$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>t. t > 0 \<longrightarrow> cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
and h1 : "t = (LEAST t. t > 0 \<and> cos t = cos (t * pi / 180))"
shows  "\<lfloor>t\<rfloor> = 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $t$ be the smallest positive real number for which $\cos t = \cos t^{\circ}$.  (We are taking the cosine of $t$ radians on the left and of $t$ degrees on the right.)  Compute $\lfloor t\rfloor$, the greatest integer less than $t$. The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Imagine two identical clock hands, each rotating counterclockwise and both initially pointing directly to the right. If one of them rotates at 1 radian per second while the other rotates at $1^{\circ}$ per second, then the faster one will sweep out an angle of $t$ radians at the same time that the slower one travels through $t$ degrees.
 We wish to know approximately when the cosines of the corresponding angles will be equal, i.e. when the $x$-coordinates of the tips of the clock hands will be the same. Clearly this will occur when the faster hand has rotated nearly all the way around the circle.
 After six seconds the slow hand will have rotated only $6^{\circ}$, while the fast hand will have traveled around 6 radians, which is still further than $6^{\circ}$ away from its starting point. (Recall that 1 radian is equal to $\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}$, which is a couple degrees less than $60^{\circ}$.)
 Therefore the $x$-coordinates will not yet be equal for the first time, but will be very close.
 We conclude that $\lfloor t\rfloor=\boxed{6}$. The interested reader may wish to compute the exact value of $t$ for which this occurs. You should find that $t= \frac{360\pi}{\pi+180}\approx 6.1754$.
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>t. t > 0 \<longrightarrow> cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
and h1 : "t = (LEAST t. t > 0 \<and> cos t = cos (t * pi / 180))"
shows  "\<lfloor>t\<rfloor> = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the smallest positive real number $t$ such that the cosine of $t$ equals the cosine of $\frac{t\pi}{180}$. What is the greatest integer less than or equal to $t$? The final answer is 6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
and h2 : "t = (LEAST x. x > 0 \<and> cos x = cos (x * pi / 180))"
shows  "floor t = 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $t$ be the smallest positive real number for which $\cos t = \cos t^{\circ}$.  (We are taking the cosine of $t$ radians on the left and of $t$ degrees on the right.)  Compute $\lfloor t\rfloor$, the greatest integer less than $t$. The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Imagine two identical clock hands, each rotating counterclockwise and both initially pointing directly to the right. If one of them rotates at 1 radian per second while the other rotates at $1^{\circ}$ per second, then the faster one will sweep out an angle of $t$ radians at the same time that the slower one travels through $t$ degrees.
 We wish to know approximately when the cosines of the corresponding angles will be equal, i.e. when the $x$-coordinates of the tips of the clock hands will be the same. Clearly this will occur when the faster hand has rotated nearly all the way around the circle.
 After six seconds the slow hand will have rotated only $6^{\circ}$, while the fast hand will have traveled around 6 radians, which is still further than $6^{\circ}$ away from its starting point. (Recall that 1 radian is equal to $\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}$, which is a couple degrees less than $60^{\circ}$.)
 Therefore the $x$-coordinates will not yet be equal for the first time, but will be very close.
 We conclude that $\lfloor t\rfloor=\boxed{6}$. The interested reader may wish to compute the exact value of $t$ for which this occurs. You should find that $t= \frac{360\pi}{\pi+180}\approx 6.1754$.
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
and h2 : "t = (LEAST x. x > 0 \<and> cos x = cos (x * pi / 180))"
shows  "floor t = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the smallest positive value of $t$ such that $cos(t) = cos(t * \pi / 180)$. Round down this value to the nearest integer. The final answer is $6$.

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t > 0"
and h1 : "cos t = cos (t * pi / 180)"
shows  "floor t = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the largest integer less than or equal to $t$, where $t$ is a positive real number such that $\cos(t) = \cos(t \cdot \pi / 180)$. The final answer is $6$.

(Recall that 1 radian is equal to $\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}$, which is a couple degrees less than $60^{\circ}$.)

 We conclude that $\lfloor t\rfloor=\boxed{6}$. The interested reader may wish to compute the exact value of $t$ for which this occurs. You should find that $t= \frac{360\pi}{\pi+180}\approx 6.1754$.
 *)

 proof-

natural solution: Imagine two identical clock hands, each rotating counterclockwise and both initially pointing directly to the right. After six seconds the slow hand will have rotated only $6^{\circ}$, while the fast hand will have traveled around 6 radians, which is still further than $6^{\circ}$ away from its starting point. (Recall that 1 radian is equal to $\frac{180^{\circ}}{\pi}$, which is a couple degrees less than $60^{\circ}$.)
Therefore the $x$-coordinates will not yet be equal for the first time, but will be very close.
We conclude that $\lfloor t\rfloor=\boxed{6}$. The interested reader may wish to compute the exact value of $t$ for which this occurs. You should find that $t= \frac{360\pi}{\pi+180}\approx 6.1754$.
